page.title: Coordination Constructions - Comparatives
page.introduction:
This section considers comparatives which have two sentences surrounding the comparative word, though the second sentence may be missing the adjective. We already covered the comparatives which are a subtype of copular sentences in
Basic Sentences - Comparatives. Like the shorter comparatives, these compare the qualities or actions of the subjects of the sentences and may have a copular verb or a perception verb or an action verb, along with an adjective that is modified by a degree word or affix. Some English examples are:

EnglishExample.exItem: John is more handsome than Bill is.
Sue runs much faster than Mary can run.
David appears lots taller than Michael does.
Mary looks prettier than Julie looks.
John seems more certain of his answers than Sue seems.

page.introduction: Some languages do not allow any part of the second sentence to be omitted and instead always have two full sentences being compared. Also, languages which do not have an independent comparative word meaning ‘than’ for the shorter comparative constructions will simply have the two sentence parts following one another in this construction.
